awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Increasing Native American perspectives in field and experimental linguistics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. It has both scientific and societal benefits, and integrates research and education. The aim of this project is to make STEM and higher education more accessible to and inclusive of American Indian/Alaska Native students through a research experience that relates directly to a topic of particular interest to American Indian/Alaska Native communities – the revitalization and scientific study of Native languages. American Indian/Alaska Native students are greatly underrepresented in academia and this situation has remained virtually unchanged for decades. A growing body of research points to the importance and need for higher education to increase its cultural competency as a critical strategy for becoming accessible to underrepresented groups, such as American Indian/Alaska Native students. Conversely, academia cannot achieve excellence without perspectives from a diversity of backgrounds to inform and improve it. Thus, the broader impact of this REU site is manifold: It uses a culturally informed and competent approach to introduce American Indian/Alaska Native students to linguistics and the various research disciplines with which linguistics intersects; in doing so it contributes towards an increase in participation of American Indian/Alaska Native students in higher education and research; and as a result, this project contributes towards strengthening academia broadly through a diversification of perspectives.
 
Through the REU site, participants complete research rotations in multiple areas of linguistics, specifically focusing on experimental linguistics and language documentation and revitalization. The program embraces a usage-based study of language within a community-centered cross-disciplinary approach, which is relatively novel in undergraduate linguistic training. REU participants are exposed to the full range of skills necessary to conduct research in linguistics. These research rotations are supplemented with coursework in topics on descriptive and experimental linguistics and academic and professional development workshops. The workshops focus on providing participants with skills to initiate careers in STEM, as well as pursuing master's and  Ph.D. degrees in linguistics or related fields. The fundamental goal of this work is to help students become active agents of innovation in STEM through linguistics, seeking to break down disciplinary silos and reprioritize the societal value of science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes

The REU site in Linguistics at the University of Oregon (UO) aimed to make STEM and higher education more inclusive of American Indian/Alaska Native (AIAN) students through a research experience that relates directly to a topic of relevance: the revitalization and study of Native American languages. AIAN students are greatly underrepresented in academia, a situation that remains unchanged after decades. Research points to the importance for higher education to increase cultural competency so that it may become accessible to underrepresented groups. Conversely, academia cannot achieve excellence without perspectives from a diversity of stakeholders.

 

This REU site ran for three summers from 2022 to 2024. 52 applications were received and 23 undergraduate students participated. In each year, students participated in a pre-program, mid-program and post-program survey. The pre- and post- surveys assessed whether the program contributed towards increasing the skills and confidence of students in pursuing work or studies in STEM. In all three summers, students reported having gained in both. The mid-way and post-program surveys assessed whether the course and workshop content responded to the academic interests and needs of the participants. The mid-way survey allowed organizers to make adjustments to ensure that any program weaknesses would be addressed in the second half of the program. The post-program survey also informed the organizers of improvements needed for the subsequent year.

 

The program ran for 8 weeks. The first week was virtual, to synchronize the semester-based programs of most students with the term-based program at UO, and to allow students to manage their transitions to the summer months (ex. move out of dorms). Course content during week 1 was aimed at cohort building, and discussions around Indigenous methodologies, linguistic diversity, and ethics in research.

 

The intellectual merit of this REU site centers on the participants completing two “rotations” of three weeks each, one in documentary and descriptive linguistics, the other in experimental linguistics. Weeks 2 to 4 provided an intensive 300-level course on linguistic analysis. This was complemented by hands-on transcription and analysis of historical documentation of the languages of the Confederated Tribes of Coos, Lower Umpqua and Siuslaw Indians who partnered with this REU site to provide this experience. Weeks 5 to 7 provided an intensive 300-level course on experimental linguistics. This was complemented by hands-on research in the Speech and Language Lab. In week 8, students presented a poster summarizing an aspect of their research. This presentation was scaffolded through dedicated training and hands-on work sessions in weeks 6 and 7.

 

The broader impact is two-fold. First, in order to contribute to the preparedness of AIAN student for STEM careers or academic programs, the program was complemented by a diversity of workshops which included library research and bibliography management, applying to graduate school, and one-on-one academic advising with the Assistant Director for the Center for Multicultural Academic Excellence. In addition, students attended presentations with a diversity of researchers in STEM fields from within the UO and outside including the Smithsonian Institution.

 

Second, the REU site aimed to effect change in the UO as an institution, to increase its cultural competence and in turn, become better suited to offer culturally sensitive higher education programs. The Many Nations Longhouse was made available to the students throughout the three summers as place for community-building. A regional elder introduced the students to aspects of the Kalapuya people whose land the UO stands on. The program offered students participation free of charge in the week-long talks and activities of the Summer Institute run by the UO Northwest Indian Language Institute. Native UO faculty and staff participated in the delivery of workshops and presentations. In years 2 and 3, a visit was made to Tribal partners in southern Oregon.

 

The REU site incorporated a peer-mentor role in 2023 and 2024 aimed at providing a dedicated peer within the organizers who would connect students to university services and the local community. In 2024, the program also incorporated the role of resident elder to share their lived experience as a language advocate and teacher, and their scholarly acumen as an academic linguist.

 

Quite crucially, in Summer 2022, the site was impacted by a number of institutional structures and processes that we identified as not culturally appropriate or inclusive. Student feedback supported the observations of the organizers. The organizers responded in year 2 by engaging in numerous conversations with units across campus to effect change. The outcome was a program during year 3 that ran smoothly, ensured that students had access to services for optimal learning, and ensured that the students time on campus would be harmonious. Survey responses assessing the cultural competence of the university and the REU site organizers and faculty were all positive. The UO Linguistics department is confident that the REU site met all its intended objectives.
